<p><strong>With its stable government,</strong> managerial and technical talent and expanding middle class,
India is poised for many years of strong economic growth. The prospects for the insurance
industry should be extraordinarily good, since Indian consumers risk coverage is low even
by emerging market standards.</p>
<p>Unlike other markets, however, growth in Indias life insurance industry is correlated more
closely to equity market performance (Exhibit 1) than rising GDP.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 1</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/financial%20services/our%20insights/the%20life%20journey%20india/svgz_life-journey-india-series_ex1.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Growth in life insurance in India correlates closely with equity markets." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/financial%20services/our%20insights/the%20life%20journey%20india/svgz_life-journey-india-series_ex1.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. <p>And profits remain elusive:
for more than a decade, the private industry has delivered overall returns far below the cost
of capital (Exhibit 2) and even below the returns in other Asian markets (Exhibit 3).</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 2</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/financial%20services/our%20insights/the%20life%20journey%20india/svgz_life-journey-india-series_ex2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Private-sector life insurers1 have delivered returns far below the cost of capital." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/financial%20services/our%20insights/the%20life%20journey%20india/svgz_life-journey-india-series_ex2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. <p>Even the bright spots are mostly illusory. Between 2011 and 2014, for example, private life
insurers in aggregate generated positive returns, but our analysis shows that this rebound
was driven primarily by surrenders and lapses on unit-linked investment products (ULIPs)
as equity markets weakened. New businesses also declined, ironically buoying industry
earnings as life insurers reduced financial strain incurred from the significant acquisition
costs incurred in the first year of selling a new policy.</p>
<p>The industrys negative returns are no surprise, since most Indian private life insurers have
chased volume by building large sales forces with significant fixed cost infrastructure and
who focus on selling low-margin ULIPs. And rather than trying to build the skills of agents to
sell higher margin protection products as affluency rises, many carriers continue to chase
top-line investment-focused growth in the hopes of building scale and growing their way out
of the profitability challenge.</p>
<p>This model may not work. Volume growth can create some value in bancassurance in situations
where the channel is proprietary and unit acquisition costs are loweras it is in the case
of Indian life insurers with exclusive bank partners, often with cross-held equity. Indeed,
investors continue to reward Indian life insurers for building top-line growth, mostly in
their bancassurance business. But our global research shows that a significantly larger
opportunity for value creation belongs to those who make the strategic shift to create value
in agency by selling a greater share of protection products.</p>
<h2>A wide gap between leaders and laggards</h2>
<p>Although the industry as a whole has destroyed value for more than a decade, our
calculations show that three carriers grew their surplus by an average of more than 25 percent per
year during that period (Exhibit 4).</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 4</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/financial%20services/our%20insights/the%20life%20journey%20india/svgz_life-journey-india-series_ex4.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="An 81 percentage point-spread in annual growth in value separates best and worst performers." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/financial%20services/our%20insights/the%20life%20journey%20india/svgz_life-journey-india-series_ex4.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>McKinsey research into value-creation amongst the 15 largest insurers in the market reveals
a 81 percentage point spread in book value growth between the top and bottom performers
from 2002 to 2013. During this period, the book value of insurers in the top quartile grew
by 19 percent to 34 percent compounded annually as opposed to 11 percent to 47 percent for those in the bottom
quartile. (To arrive at this conclusion, we made significant adjustments to reported returns,
as explained in the sidebar.)</p>
<p>

class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-outer__UdWCq"><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__eyebrow__5GSEq">Sidebar</div><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content__raEwe"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>Measuring the performance of a life insurer</div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><p>We believe the most revealing metric to measure growth in the value of a life
insurer is growth in adjusted statutory book valuei.e., the ability to grow
surplus adjusting for dividends to shareholders and capital injections. Adjusted
growth in surplus is a relevant metric for measuring the performance of life
insurers carriers because it accounts for profitability as well as growth. Adjusted growth in surplus allows for an apples-to-apples comparison between mutuals and stock-traded carriers since price-to-book is a common way to value stock-traded carriers and mutuals as they strive to grow their grow their surplus, and
it correlates well over time with other measures including return on equity, total
return to shareholders, and economic value creation.</p></div></div></div></div></div></div>
</p>
<p>The wide spread in value creation is not unique to Indiacarriers in Japan showed a 28
percentage point spread in annual growth rates in book value, for example, the spread
amongst the top 30 US carriers is 13 percentage points, and Chinas are separated by as
many as 55 percentage pointsbut the variation in performance raises important questions.<span class="footnote-holder"><a rel="#footnote1" class="link-footnote footnote-wrapper" aria-describedby="dd5aa0a1-5390-4ba0-823f-692a1b597849" tabindex="0" aria-label="footnote" style="cursor: pointer;"><sup class="footnotesup">1</sup><span class="notch-wrapper"><span class="notch"></span></span><span id="footnote1" class="tooltip" style=""><span class="footnote-content"><span class="footnote-number">1.</span><span class="footnote-text" id="dd5aa0a1-5390-4ba0-823f-692a1b597849"><span></span>The Life Journey series.</span><span class="clear"></span></span><span class="footnote-bottom"></span></span></a></span> 
What do the winners do differently in India? Do they offer a more attractive product mix?
Execute better within product lines? Achieve higher investment returns?</p>
<p>We launched a research effortThe Life Journeyto develop fact-based answers to these
questions in India. We analyzed publicly available data for Indias life insurance industry since
2000 and for the top 15 life insurers since 2003, and we interviewed more than two dozen
industry analysts and executives.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-disruptor1up mck-o-md-center mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom mck-u-screen-only" data-layer-region="disruptor-1up"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-md mdc-u-grid-col-lg-12 mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 "><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-12"><header data-component="mdc-c-header" class="mdc-c-header"><div class="mdc-c-header__block___i1Lg-_990311c"><h3 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c"><div>Would you like to learn more about our <a href="/industries/financial-services/how-we-help-clients">Financial Services Practice</a>?</div></h3></div></header><div data-component="mdc-c-link-container" class="mdc-c-link-container___xefGu_990311c mdc-c-link-container--display-column___X0HDD_990311c mck-c-disruptor1up__content Disruptor1Up_mck-c-disruptor1up__content--links__VV4lE mdc-u-grid-gutter-md"><a data-component="mdc-c-link" href="/industries/financial-services/how-we-help-clients/insurance" class="mdc-c-link-cta___NBQVi_990311c"><span class="mdc-c-link__label___Pfqtd_990311c">Visit our Insurance page</span><span data-component="mdc-c-icon" class="mdc-c-icon___oi7ef_990311c mck-link-arrow-right-icon"></span></a></div></div></div></div>
<p>Our research revealed that none of the private insurers in the country are creating value as per the market potential. This is because they are all serving a miniscule segment of
consumers, mainly to meet narrow investment needs. But even within this confined space,
they demonstrate a significant spread in performance which is driven largely by distribution
strategy.</p>
<p>While most carriers offer affluent consumers a similar product mix, including a high share
of investment-focused ULIPs, a few have outperformed the industry by investing in their
distribution channels. The leaders tend to focus on bancassurance, for example, and
leverage strategic and exclusive partnerships with banks to leverage their scale, footprint,
and brand to grow market share and profit margins.</p>
<p>The implication is that while life insurers carriers can grow value by learning from industry
leaders who are doing well in bancassurance, the overwhelming value creation potential lies
in rethinking the industrys value proposition to serve the protection needs of a much larger
segment of the population. To grow value, life insurers in India must create, market, and sell
more protection products.</p>
<p>McKinseys analysis of life insurers around the world reveals that whilst all markets show a
significant performance gap between the top and the bottom players, the major driver of
this performance gap depends on the economic maturity.<span class="footnote-holder"><a rel="#footnote2" class="link-footnote footnote-wrapper" aria-describedby="1731c3b0-4fba-495b-a879-c3a1962d1b11" tabindex="0" aria-label="footnote" style="cursor: pointer;"><sup class="footnotesup">2</sup><span class="notch-wrapper"><span class="notch"></span></span><span id="footnote2" class="tooltip" style=""><span class="footnote-content"><span class="footnote-number">2.</span><span class="footnote-text" id="1731c3b0-4fba-495b-a879-c3a1962d1b11"><span></span>The Life Journey series.</span><span class="clear"></span></span><span class="footnote-bottom"></span></span></a></span>  For example, in more mature
economies such as the US and Japan, higher-performing life insurers generate value through
superior liability risk management; those in emerging economies such as India, meanwhile, rely almost entirely on asset management. In other words, as markets mature, the basis of
value-creation shifts from assets to liabilities (Exhibit 5). Investment management remains
a significant source of earnings in every market, of course, but carriers find it increasingly
difficult over time to differentiate their performance purely on this basis.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 5</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/financial%20services/our%20insights/the%20life%20journey%20india/svgz-life-journey-india-ex5.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Value creation shifts from assets to liabilities as markets mature" src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/financial%20services/our%20insights/the%20life%20journey%20india/svgz-life-journey-india-ex5.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>We expect that as the institutional asset management market matures in India, it will erode
life insurers ability to deliver high returns on the asset side of the balance sheet and force
them into building capabilities that create value on the liability side.</p>
<p>Korea, China, and Indonesia and other emerging markets have already begun to undergo
this shift. We believe that in the next decade life insurers carriers in India will create value
consistently only by mastering liability management: pricing and selecting risk more wisely,
designing more protection products, and building the distribution skills to sell them.</p>
<p>Relative to other markets, the Indian insurance market is also unique in how channels
stack up in value contribution. In other markets except Indonesia, tied agency creates
more value than third parties including bancassurance. In India, third-party channelsbancassurance accounting for the overwhelming majority of itcreate more value than
agency (Exhibit 6).</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 6</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/financial%20services/our%20insights/the%20life%20journey%20india/svgz_life-journey-india-series_ex6.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Value creation by type of channel" src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/financial%20services/our%20insights/the%20life%20journey%20india/svgz_life-journey-india-series_ex6.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p> In fact, bancassurance is now the largest channel for Indias private-sector insurers, constituting about 55 percent of the market (Exhibit 7) and contributing to surplus
growth at a rate that is 50 percent higher than that in agency.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 7</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/financial%20services/our%20insights/the%20life%20journey%20india/svgz_life-journey-india-series_ex7.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Bancassurance is the dominant sales channel among private-sector life insurers in India." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/financial%20services/our%20insights/the%20life%20journey%20india/svgz_life-journey-india-series_ex7.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. <h2>The search for profitable growth</h2>
<p>In what may be the worlds most promising insurance market, we see the largest untapped
potential in two areas: growing penetration in a few specific geographies and unleashing
latent demand for protection products.</p>
<h3>Go granular to identify high growth geographies</h3>
<p>The Indian economy will grow rapidly in the years ahead, but the gains will vary widely by
geography. We expect 44 clusters and five stand-alone regions to account for over three-fourths of Indias incremental GDP growth by 2025 (Exhibit 8). Opportunities in mid-sized
cities, such as Kochi and Surat, will be larger than those in major cities like Mumbai and
Delhi.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 8</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/financial%20services/our%20insights/the%20life%20journey%20india/svgz-life-journey-india-ex8-final.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Fewer than 50 metropolitan clusters and five standalone markets will deliver 80% of incremental GDP through 2025." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/financial%20services/our%20insights/the%20life%20journey%20india/svgz-life-journey-india-ex8-final.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>Even within cities, insurers must use a micromarket lens to allocate resources and build
distribution capacity (Exhibit 9). Mumbai, for example, has 33 distinct micromarkets across
more than 150 wards, of which eight will account for three-quarters of the citys growth in
the next decade.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 9</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/financial%20services/our%20insights/the%20life%20journey%20india/svgz-life-journey-india-ex9.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Each micro-market requires a customized approach" src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/financial%20services/our%20insights/the%20life%20journey%20india/svgz-life-journey-india-ex9.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<h3>Shift from investment to protection</h3>
<p>As affluence rises, demand for protection, pensions, annuities, and long-term care products will
provide significant opportunities for growth.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-disruptor1up mck-o-md-center mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom mck-u-screen-only" data-layer-region="disruptor-1up"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-md mdc-u-grid-col-lg-12 mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 "><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-lg-span-4 mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-5 Disruptor1Up_mck-c-disruptor1up__image___2Gc4"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture"><img alt="The life journey China" src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/financial%20services/our%20insights/the%20life%20journey%20china/jpg_life_journey_china_400.jpg?cq=50&mh=145&car=16:9&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-lg-span-8 mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-7"><header data-component="mdc-c-header" class="mdc-c-header"><div class="mdc-c-header__block___i1Lg-_990311c"><h3 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c"><div>The life journey China</div></h3></div></header><div data-component="mdc-c-link-container" class="mdc-c-link-container___xefGu_990311c mdc-c-link-container--display-column___X0HDD_990311c mck-c-disruptor1up__content Disruptor1Up_mck-c-disruptor1up__content--links__VV4lE mdc-u-grid-gutter-md"><a data-component="mdc-c-link" href="/industries/financial-services/our-insights/the-life-journey-china" class="mdc-c-link-cta___NBQVi_990311c"><span class="mdc-c-link__label___Pfqtd_990311c">Read the article</span><span data-component="mdc-c-icon" class="mdc-c-icon___oi7ef_990311c mck-link-arrow-right-icon"></span></a></div></div></div></div>
<p>Around the world, managing poolable riskmortality and morbidityis the single biggest
driver of value-creation in life insurance, but India remains highly underpenetrated in terms of risk
and protection products. In level of sum assured to GDP ratio, India is at 50, while Thailand is at
96, Malaysia 149, Korea 166, and the US at 270.</p>
<p>Demand for these products in India has already begun to grow sharply (Exhibit 10), with the
accident and health segment leading the way. This market has historically been dominated
by non-life players, but life carriers can capture a sizeable share of this market with innovative
products and services and, most important, a distinctive value proposition of advice and service
through the agency channel.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 10</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/financial%20services/our%20insights/the%20life%20journey%20india/svgz_life-journey-india-series_ex10.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Demand for life and health insurance is growing rapidly." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/financial%20services/our%20insights/the%20life%20journey%20india/svgz_life-journey-india-series_ex10.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>The penetration of retirement products is also extremely low, but Indian consumers across
segments are increasingly concerned with the risks they face in retirement (Exhibit 11). As their
awareness grows, consumers will expect better yields, more security, and a steady source of
post-retirement income that life insurers are uniquely positioned to provide.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 11</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/financial%20services/our%20insights/the%20life%20journey%20india/svgz_life-journey-india-series_ex11.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Individual annuities and pensions are growing rapidly." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/financial%20services/our%20insights/the%20life%20journey%20india/svgz_life-journey-india-series_ex11.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<h2>Four imperatives for life insurers seeking value growth</h2>
<p>To ride the wave of growth in India and deliver sustainable value in the years ahead, we believe life
insurers will need to strengthen their capabilities in four key areas:</p>
<ol>
    <li>
    <p><strong>Expand capabilities in agency and lower costs.</strong> Sales forces in India range from the
    rare professional teams serving the affluent to the ubiquitous part-time sales people
    who concentrate on the mass market. We believe that to grow value, insurers must first
    prioritize customer segmentsbased on profit pool size and growth, and their own
    competitive advantage. Then, based on the size of the opportunity, starting position, and
    appetite for risk and time to maturity, each carrier should align on an agency strategy.
    The levers it chooses to drive agency performance will depend on this strategy.<span class="footnote-holder"><a rel="#footnote3" class="link-footnote footnote-wrapper" aria-describedby="b125f329-d608-4cc5-ba84-0066f854eaab" tabindex="0" aria-label="footnote" style="cursor: pointer;"><sup class="footnotesup">3</sup><span class="notch-wrapper"><span class="notch"></span></span><span id="footnote3" class="tooltip" style=""><span class="footnote-content"><span class="footnote-number">3.</span><span class="footnote-text" id="b125f329-d608-4cc5-ba84-0066f854eaab"><span></span>For details, see Maximizing Value from Agency in Asia published by the McKinsey Financial Services Practice in 2015.</span><span class="clear"></span></span><span class="footnote-bottom"></span></span></a></span> </p>
    <p>Regardless of the strategic footprint life insurers choose, they must also invest in a few areas, including tailoring service offerings to agents based on their needs, increasing financial-planning
    uptake, building product-expert, wholesaler, and sales teams to drive agent
    performance. In addition, life insurers in India must rethink the frontline manager model
    to improve effectiveness and significantly lower fixed costs.</p>
    </li>
    <li>
    <p><strong>Reinvent relationships with customers and distributors by using digital tools
    and analytics.</strong> Indian consumers are becoming more digital, crossing boundaries
    seamlessly between the physical and virtual worlds in their decision journeys. Marketing
    innovations using social and digital media, including online product customization and
    purchasing and multichannel experiences, are becoming requirements for life insurers
    to remain competitive in India. In addition, with increasing competition, efficiency will
    become even more important. To improve efficiency ratios, insurers should invest in
    digitization, lean distribution, analytics, and better management of in-force customers.
    These skills will help make advances across the industry value chain: sales, product
    design and pricing, risk selection, claims, and service.</p>
    </li>
    <li>
    <p><strong>Build risk and capital management skills.</strong> As described earlier, to grow value and
    outperform the industry, Indias life insurers will need to excel in managing liability risks. The winners will rely on clear parameters regarding risk appetite and establish robust
    metrics to manage capital and govern risk. Winners will also build more flexibility
    into product design and pricing to make fewer long-term guarantees and find more
    innovative ways to share risk with policyholders.</p>
    </li>
    <li>
    <p><strong>Leverage the in-force book and existing customer relationships.</strong> The in-force book
    accounts for a large share of profits, revenues, and operating costs for insurers, and
    this share will only increase as the industry matures. To unlock the hidden value of the
    in-force book, carriers need to capitalize on pricing, fee, and asset-allocation flexibility,
    pursue cross-selling and customer behavior management, and improve operational
    efficiency.</p>
    </li>
</ol>
<hr>
<p>For Indias life insurers, the challenge is straightforward: stable, attractive returns will come
only to those who fundamentally rethink the industrys value proposition and shift focus
on serving the protection needs of a broader share of the population by building capabilities
to effectively manage liability risk and by building a more efficient and effective distribution
model.</p></div><div class="container-placeholder"></div></div></div><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-xl"><section role="contentinfo" data-layer-region="article-about-authors" class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 AboutAuthor_mck-c-about-author__nRJzu"><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-start-2 mdc-u-grid-col-md-end-12 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-start-3 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-end-11"><h5 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-c-heading--title___5qyOB_990311c mdc-c-heading--border___K8dj3_990311c mdc-u-align-center">About the author(s)</h5><div data-component="mdc-c-description" class="mdc-c-description___SrnQP_990311c mdc-u-ts-8 mck-u-links-inline mck-u-links-inline--secondary mdc-u-mt-5"><div><p><strong>Vivek Agrawal</strong> is a director in McKinseys Tokyo office, and <strong>Peeyush Dalmia</strong> is a principal in the Mumbai office.</p>
<p>The authors wish to thank Alessia de Bustis and Sandeep Kumar for their contributions to this article.</p></div></div></div></section><section class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 \u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWith its stable government,\u003c/strong\u003e managerial and technical talent and expanding middle class,\nIndia is poised for many years of strong economic growth. The prospects for the insurance\nindustry should be extraordinarily good, since Indian consumers\u0026rsquo; risk coverage is low even\nby emerging market standards.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eUnlike other markets, however, growth in India\u0026rsquo;s life insurance industry is correlated more\nclosely to equity market performance (Exhibit 1) than rising GDP.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[exhibit 1]]\n\u003cp\u003eAnd profits remain elusive:\nfor more than a decade, the private industry has delivered overall returns far below the cost\nof capital (Exhibit 2) and even below the returns in other Asian markets (Exhibit 3).\u003c/p\u003e\n[[exhibit 2]]\n[[exhibit 3]]\n\u003cp\u003eEven the bright spots are mostly illusory. Between 2011 and 2014, for example, private life\ninsurers in aggregate generated positive returns, but our analysis shows that this rebound\nwas driven primarily by surrenders and lapses on unit-linked investment products (ULIPs)\nas equity markets weakened. New businesses also declined, ironically buoying industry\nearnings as life insurers reduced financial strain incurred from the significant acquisition\ncosts incurred in the first year of selling a new policy.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe industry\u0026rsquo;s negative returns are no surprise, since most Indian private life insurers have\nchased volume by building large sales forces with significant fixed cost infrastructure and\nwho focus on selling low-margin ULIPs. And rather than trying to build the skills of agents to\nsell higher margin protection products as affluency rises, many carriers continue to chase\ntop-line investment-focused growth in the hopes of building scale and growing their way out\nof the profitability challenge.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis model may not work. Volume growth can create some value in bancassurance in situations\nwhere the channel is proprietary and unit acquisition costs are lower\u0026mdash;as it is in the case\nof Indian life insurers with exclusive bank partners, often with cross-held equity. Indeed,\ninvestors continue to reward Indian life insurers for building top-line growth, mostly in\ntheir bancassurance business. But our global research shows that a significantly larger\nopportunity for value creation belongs to those who make the strategic shift to create value\nin agency by selling a greater share of protection products.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eA wide gap between leaders and laggards\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAlthough the industry as a whole has destroyed value for more than a decade, our\ncalculations show that three carriers grew their surplus by an average of more than 25 percent per\nyear during that period (Exhibit 4).\u003c/p\u003e\n[[exhibit 4]]\n\u003cp\u003eMcKinsey research into value-creation amongst the 15 largest insurers in the market reveals\na 81 percentage point spread in book value growth between the top and bottom performers\nfrom 2002 to 2013. During this period, the book value of insurers in the top quartile grew\nby 19 percent to 34 percent compounded annually as opposed to \u0026ndash;11 percent to \u0026ndash;47 percent for those in the bottom\nquartile. (To arrive at this conclusion, we made significant adjustments to reported returns,\nas explained in the sidebar.)\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\n[[sidebar Sidebar]]\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe wide spread in value creation is not unique to India\u0026mdash;carriers in Japan showed a 28\npercentage point spread in annual growth rates in book value, for example, the spread\namongst the top 30 US carriers is 13 percentage points, and China\u0026rsquo;s are separated by as\nmany as 55 percentage points\u0026mdash;but the variation in performance raises important questions.\u003ca href=\"#\" class=\"link-footnote\" onclick=\"return false;\" rel=\"#footnote1\"\u003e\u003csup\u003e1\u003c/sup\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003cspan class=\"tooltip\" id=\"footnote1\" style=\"display: none;\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-content\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-number\"\u003e1.\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-text\"\u003eThe Life Journey series.\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"clear\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-bottom\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\nWhat do the winners do differently in India? Do they offer a more attractive product mix?\nExecute better within product lines? Achieve higher investment returns?\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWe launched a research effort\u0026mdash;The Life Journey\u0026mdash;to develop fact-based answers to these\nquestions in India. We analyzed publicly available data for India\u0026rsquo;s life insurance industry since\n2000 and for the top 15 life insurers since 2003, and we interviewed more than two dozen\nindustry analysts and executives.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[disruptor1Up dis1]]\n\u003cp\u003eOur research revealed that none of the private insurers in the country are creating value as per the market potential. This is because they are all serving a miniscule segment of\nconsumers, mainly to meet narrow investment needs. But even within this confined space,\nthey demonstrate a significant spread in performance which is driven largely by distribution\nstrategy.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhile most carriers offer affluent consumers a similar product mix, including a high share\nof investment-focused ULIPs, a few have outperformed the industry by investing in their\ndistribution channels. The leaders tend to focus on bancassurance, for example, and\nleverage strategic and exclusive partnerships with banks to leverage their scale, footprint,\nand brand to grow market share and profit margins.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe implication is that while life insurers carriers can grow value by learning from industry\nleaders who are doing well in bancassurance, the overwhelming value creation potential lies\nin rethinking the industry\u0026rsquo;s value proposition to serve the protection needs of a much larger\nsegment of the population. To grow value, life insurers in India must create, market, and sell\nmore protection products.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMcKinsey\u0026rsquo;s analysis of life insurers around the world reveals that whilst all markets show a\nsignificant performance gap between the top and the bottom players, the major driver of\nthis performance gap depends on the economic maturity.\u003ca href=\"#\" class=\"link-footnote\" onclick=\"return false;\" rel=\"#footnote2\"\u003e\u003csup\u003e2\u003c/sup\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003cspan class=\"tooltip\" id=\"footnote2\" style=\"display: none;\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-content\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-number\"\u003e2.\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-text\"\u003eThe Life Journey series.\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"clear\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-bottom\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e For example, in more mature\neconomies such as the US and Japan, higher-performing life insurers generate value through\nsuperior liability risk management; those in emerging economies such as India, meanwhile, rely almost entirely on asset management. In other words, as markets mature, the basis of\nvalue-creation shifts from assets to liabilities (Exhibit 5). Investment management remains\na significant source of earnings in every market, of course, but carriers find it increasingly\ndifficult over time to differentiate their performance purely on this basis.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[exhibit 5]]\n\u003cp\u003eWe expect that as the institutional asset management market matures in India, it will erode\nlife insurers\u0026rsquo; ability to deliver high returns on the asset side of the balance sheet and force\nthem into building capabilities that create value on the liability side.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eKorea, China, and Indonesia and other emerging markets have already begun to undergo\nthis shift. We believe that in the next decade life insurers carriers in India will create value\nconsistently only by mastering liability management: pricing and selecting risk more wisely,\ndesigning more protection products, and building the distribution skills to sell them.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eRelative to other markets, the Indian insurance market is also unique in how channels\nstack up in value contribution. In other markets except Indonesia, tied agency creates\nmore value than third parties including bancassurance. In India, third-party channels\u0026mdash;bancassurance accounting for the overwhelming majority of it\u0026mdash;create more value than\nagency (Exhibit 6).\u003c/p\u003e\n[[exhibit 6]]\n\u003cp\u003e In fact, bancassurance is now the largest channel for India\u0026rsquo;s private-sector insurers, constituting about 55 percent of the market (Exhibit 7) and contributing to surplus\ngrowth at a rate that is 50 percent higher than that in agency.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[exhibit 7]]\n\u003ch2\u003eThe search for profitable growth\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn what may be the world\u0026rsquo;s most promising insurance market, we see the largest untapped\npotential in two areas: growing penetration in a few specific geographies and unleashing\nlatent demand for protection products.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003e\u0026lsquo;Go granular\u0026rsquo; to identify high growth geographies\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe Indian economy will grow rapidly in the years ahead, but the gains will vary widely by\ngeography. We expect 44 clusters and five stand-alone regions to account for over three-fourths of India\u0026rsquo;s incremental GDP growth by 2025 (Exhibit 8). Opportunities in mid-sized\ncities, such as Kochi and Surat, will be larger than those in major cities like Mumbai and\nDelhi.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[exhibit 8]]\n\u003cp\u003eEven within cities, insurers must use a micromarket lens to allocate resources and build\ndistribution capacity (Exhibit 9). Mumbai, for example, has 33 distinct micromarkets across\nmore than 150 wards, of which eight will account for three-quarters of the city\u0026rsquo;s growth in\nthe next decade.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[exhibit 9]]\n\u003ch3\u003eShift from investment to protection\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAs affluence rises, demand for protection, pensions, annuities, and long-term care products will\nprovide significant opportunities for growth.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[disruptor1Up dis2]]\n\u003cp\u003eAround the world, managing \u0026ldquo;poolable risk\u0026rdquo;\u0026mdash;mortality and morbidity\u0026mdash;is the single biggest\ndriver of value-creation in life insurance, but India remains highly underpenetrated in terms of risk\nand protection products. In level of sum assured to GDP ratio, India is at 50, while Thailand is at\n96, Malaysia 149, Korea 166, and the US at 270.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDemand for these products in India has already begun to grow sharply (Exhibit 10), with the\naccident and health segment leading the way. This market has historically been dominated\nby non-life players, but life carriers can capture a sizeable share of this market with innovative\nproducts and services and, most important, a distinctive value proposition of advice and service\nthrough the agency channel.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[exhibit 10]]\n\u003cp\u003eThe penetration of retirement products is also extremely low, but Indian consumers across\nsegments are increasingly concerned with the risks they face in retirement (Exhibit 11). As their\nawareness grows, consumers will expect better yields, more security, and a steady source of\npost-retirement income that life insurers are uniquely positioned to provide.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[exhibit 11]]\n\u003ch2\u003eFour imperatives for life insurers seeking value growth\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTo ride the wave of growth in India and deliver sustainable value in the years ahead, we believe life\ninsurers will need to strengthen their capabilities in four key areas:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003col\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\n    \u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eExpand capabilities in agency and lower costs.\u003c/strong\u003e Sales forces in India range from the\n    rare professional teams serving the affluent to the ubiquitous part-time sales people\n    who concentrate on the mass market. We believe that to grow value, insurers must first\n    prioritize customer segments\u0026mdash;based on profit pool size and growth, and their own\n    competitive advantage. Then, based on the size of the opportunity, starting position, and\n    appetite for risk and time to maturity, each carrier should align on an agency strategy.\n    The levers it chooses to drive agency performance will depend on this strategy.\u003ca href=\"#\" class=\"link-footnote\" onclick=\"return false;\" rel=\"#footnote3\"\u003e\u003csup\u003e3\u003c/sup\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003cspan class=\"tooltip\" id=\"footnote3\" style=\"display: none;\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-content\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-number\"\u003e3.\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-text\"\u003eFor details, see \u0026ldquo;Maximizing Value from Agency in Asia\u0026rdquo; published by the McKinsey Financial Services Practice in 2015.\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"clear\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-bottom\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n    \u003cp\u003eRegardless of the strategic footprint life insurers choose, they must also invest in a few areas, including tailoring service offerings to agents based on their needs, increasing financial-planning\n    uptake, building product-expert, wholesaler, and sales teams to drive agent\n    performance. In addition, life insurers in India must rethink the frontline manager model\n    to improve effectiveness and significantly lower fixed costs.\u003c/p\u003e\n    \u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\n    \u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eReinvent relationships with customers and distributors by using digital tools\n    and analytics.\u003c/strong\u003e Indian consumers are becoming more digital, crossing boundaries\n    seamlessly between the physical and virtual worlds in their decision journeys. Marketing\n    innovations using social and digital media, including online product customization and\n    purchasing and multichannel experiences, are becoming requirements for life insurers\n    to remain competitive in India. In addition, with increasing competition, efficiency will\n    become even more important. To improve efficiency ratios, insurers should invest in\n    digitization, lean distribution, analytics, and better management of in-force customers.\n    These skills will help make advances across the industry value chain: sales, product\n    design and pricing, risk selection, claims, and service.\u003c/p\u003e\n    \u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\n    \u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eBuild risk and capital management skills.\u003c/strong\u003e As described earlier, to grow value and\n    outperform the industry, India\u0026rsquo;s life insurers will need to excel in managing liability risks. The winners will rely on clear parameters regarding risk appetite and establish robust\n    metrics to manage capital and govern risk. Winners will also build more flexibility\n    into product design and pricing to make fewer long-term guarantees and find more\n    innovative ways to share risk with policyholders.\u003c/p\u003e\n    \u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\n    \u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eLeverage the in-force book and existing customer relationships.\u003c/strong\u003e The in-force book\n    accounts for a large share of profits, revenues, and operating costs for insurers, and\n    this share will only increase as the industry matures. To unlock the hidden value of the\n    in-force book, carriers need to capitalize on pricing, fee, and asset-allocation flexibility,\n    pursue cross-selling and customer behavior management, and improve operational\n    efficiency.\u003c/p\u003e\n    \u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ol\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFor India\u0026rsquo;s life insurers, the challenge is straightforward: stable, attractive returns will come\nonly to those who fundamentally rethink the industry\u0026rsquo;s value proposition and shift focus\non serving the protection needs of a broader share of the population by building capabilities\nto effectively manage liability risk and by building a more efficient and effective distribution\nmodel.\u003c/p\u003e"},"isFullScreenInteractive":{"boolValue":false},"hideStickySocialShareBar":{"boolValue":false},"desktopID":{"value":""},"mobileID":{"value":""},"desktopURL":{"value":""},"mobileURL":{"value":""},"desktopPaddingPercentage":{"value":""},"mobilePaddingPercentage":{"value":""},"desktopOverrideHeight":{"value":""},"mobileOverrideHeight":{"value":""},"cerosOembedURL":{"value":""},"cerosRenderMode":{"targetItem":null},"cerosBackgroundColor":{"targetItem":null},"hideByLine":{"boolValue":false},"tableOfContentsTitle":{"value":"TABLE
